intro: Muscari armeniacum, commonly known as the grape hyacinth, is a bulbous plant native to the eastern Mediterranean region. It produces dense clusters of small, bell-shaped flowers that range in color from blue to purple, resembling grapes, hence its common name. The plant typically grows to a height of 10–20 cm and thrives in well-drained soil in full sun to partial shade. It is a hardy perennial that is often cultivated in gardens for its ornamental value and early spring bloom. Muscari armeniacum is also valued for its ability to naturalize and spread easily in suitable conditions.
